Answer: Yes, Pamidronate has been shown to improve chemically induced trinitrobenzenesulfonic acid and dextran sulfate sodium colitis in rats and lymphocyte transfer colitis. Pamidronate has no effect on intestinal epithelial cells in vitro in terms of cytokine/chemokine release, but enhances IFN-γ, IL-6, and IL-10 production by T cells in coculture. Pamidronate also exerts a direct immunomodulatory effect on T cells, favoring Th1 differentiation and impairing Th17 polarization.

In addition, Pamidronate has been shown to have antiinflammatory effects at the cardiovascular level due to inhibition of prenylation, which also probably underlies its therapeutic effects in preclinical models of inflammatory bowel disease. Another inhibitor of prenylation, namely alendronate, has also been shown to reduce colitis in rodents.

Overall, Pamidronate has shown promise as an intestinal antiinflammatory agent in rat and mouse experimental colitis, and further studies are needed to determine its potential therapeutic benefits in humans.

Yes, Chlamydia pneumoniae infection has been associated with atherosclerotic plaque instability in patients with established carotid artery stenosis. This association has been observed in studies using molecular biological detection methods and clinically relevant indicators of pathology in carotid artery atheroma. The presence of C pneumoniae correlates with plaque instability, which may increase the risk of atherothrombotic emboli dislodging from an unstable carotid plaque during carotid endarterectomy.

Question: Does chlamydia pneumoniae infection influence clinical outcomes in patients with established carotid artery stenosis?
Answer:
It is unclear whether Chlamydia pneumoniae infection influences clinical outcomes in patients with established carotid artery stenosis. While there is evidence of an association between the presence of C pneumoniae and atherosclerotic plaque instability, it is not clear whether this association has any clinical significance. Further research is needed to clarify the role of C pneumoniae infection in the development and progression of atherosclerotic disease.
